counselor_perspectives.overall_philosophy: Columbia seeks students who are ready to engage with the Core Curriculum and New York City. We look for intellectual curiosity, engagement with big ideas, and students who will thrive in our unique urban environment while building community.
counselor_perspectives.mission_alignment: Columbia's Core Curriculum requires all students to engage with foundational texts in literature, philosophy, science, and the arts. Admissions seeks students excited by this rigorous common intellectual experience and ready to contribute to classroom discussions.
what_they_seek: Intellectual engagement with big ideas and texts
Readiness for Core Curriculum's intensive reading and discussion
Students who will engage with NYC as an extension of campus
Diverse perspectives to enrich Core discussions
Students who thrive in structured academic environment
counselor_perspectives.evaluation_philosophy: Columbia's holistic review emphasizes fit with the Core Curriculum and urban campus. They seek students who will actively engage in seminar-style classes and take advantage of NYC's cultural and intellectual resources.

academic_criteria.gpa_expectations: Nearly all admitted students in top 10% of class, typically 3.9-4.0 unweighted GPA

test_scores.testing_requirement: Test-flexible policy - can submit SAT, ACT, or three AP exam scores
test_scores.superscoring: Yes, Columbia superscores SAT and ACT

academic_criteria.course_rigor: Most demanding curriculum available. Strong preparation in humanities, sciences, and mathematics expected for Core success.
academic_criteria.academic_interests: Values intellectual breadth - Core requires engagement across disciplines

essay_requirements.personal_statement: Common Application or Coalition Application essay (650 words)
essay_requirements.supplemental_essays: Multiple Columbia supplements including 'Why Columbia?' and intellectual interest questions; separate essays for Columbia College vs. Engineering
essay_requirements.essay_philosophy: Columbia wants to see genuine intellectual curiosity and specific understanding of the Core Curriculum and NYC location. Essays should demonstrate readiness for rigorous academic community and urban environment.
what_makes_strong_essays: Specific knowledge of Core Curriculum and genuine enthusiasm for it
Understanding of how NYC enhances education
Intellectual depth and engagement with ideas
Specific courses, professors, or programs at Columbia
How you'll contribute to classroom discussions
Balance between intellectual pursuits and community engagement
Authentic voice and reflection
common_essay_mistakes: Generic 'Why Columbia' without mentioning Core Curriculum
Focusing only on NYC location without academic substance
Not understanding what Core Curriculum actually entails
Missing opportunities to show intellectual engagement
Weak Columbia College vs. Engineering school differentiation
Listing famous programs without personal connection

extracurriculars.importance: Very high - Columbia evaluates leadership and impact
extracurriculars.depth_vs_breadth: Depth and sustained commitment preferred over breadth
extracurriculars.leadership_expectations: Leadership valued, including intellectual leadership and initiative
extracurriculars.impact_demonstration: Show sustained involvement and measurable outcomes
extracurriculars.recognition_level: Mix of highly recognized achievements and deep local impact
extracurriculars.unique_preference: Civic engagement, urban-focused activities, intellectual pursuits, activities showing engagement with diverse communities

letters_of_recommendation.requirements: Two teacher recommendations plus counselor recommendation
what_reviewers_look_for: Contribution to classroom discussions (crucial for Core success)
Intellectual curiosity and engagement with ideas
Ability to work with diverse perspectives
letters_of_recommendation.importance: Critical - recommendations should demonstrate readiness for discussion-based Core classes

demonstrated_interest.importance: Not officially tracked, but 'Why Columbia' essay must show genuine knowledge
demonstrated_interest.interviews: Alumni interviews offered when available but not required

evaluation_rubrics.selection_process: Applications reviewed by multiple readers. Strong applications discussed in committee.
evaluation_rubrics.committee_review: Admissions committee makes decisions after holistic review and discussion
evaluation_rubrics.decision_framework: Evaluation based on academic achievement, fit with Core Curriculum, extracurricular impact, essays, and recommendations
key_evaluation_points: Academic preparation for rigorous Core Curriculum
Intellectual curiosity and engagement with big ideas
Potential to thrive in NYC urban environment

unique_insights: Core Curriculum is defining feature - all students read same foundational texts, engage in seminars
NYC location is both campus and classroom - Columbia seeks students who will engage with city
Urban campus requires students to build community intentionally - different from traditional campuses
Test-flexible policy allows three AP scores instead of SAT/ACT
Columbia College focuses on liberal arts, Engineering school (SEAS) on applied science
Competition is intense - one of lowest acceptance rates among Ivies (~3.9%)
Strong emphasis on civic engagement and public service
Location near Harlem and partnership with community shapes institutional values
common_pitfalls: Not understanding or mentioning Core Curriculum in application
Treating NYC as a tourist attraction rather than educational resource
Generic essays that could apply to any urban university
Not differentiating between Columbia College and Engineering school
Missing opportunities to show intellectual engagement with texts and ideas
Underestimating importance of classroom discussion skills
Not demonstrating community-building in urban context
Weak understanding of Columbia's specific academic structure
red_flags: No mention of Core Curriculum or misunderstanding what it is
Lack of intellectual curiosity or engagement with ideas
Recommendations that don't show classroom participation
Essays focused only on location/prestige without academic substance

counselor_perspectives.overall_philosophy: Penn seeks students who demonstrate passion for learning, commitment to their community, and desire to make an impact. We value the integration of knowledge across disciplines and putting theory into practice.
counselor_perspectives.mission_alignment: Penn's focus on interdisciplinary learning and practical application drives admissions. The university values students who cross traditional boundaries between disciplines and connect classroom learning to real-world impact.
what_they_seek: Practical application of knowledge - 'theory and practice'
Students who will take advantage of Penn's resources across four undergraduate schools
Pre-professional mindset combined with liberal arts foundation
counselor_perspectives.evaluation_philosophy: Penn's holistic review emphasizes fit with specific undergraduate school (College, Wharton, Engineering, Nursing) while valuing interdisciplinary exploration. Demonstrated interest in Penn's unique offerings is important.

academic_criteria.gpa_expectations: Most admitted students in top 10% of class, typically 3.9-4.0 unweighted GPA

test_scores.superscoring: Yes, Penn superscores SAT and ACT

academic_criteria.course_rigor: Most rigorous curriculum available. Expectations vary by school - Wharton and Engineering expect strong quantitative preparation.
academic_criteria.academic_interests: Values interdisciplinary interests and ability to cross traditional academic boundaries

essay_requirements.personal_statement: Common Application or Coalition Application essay (650 words)
essay_requirements.supplemental_essays: Multiple Penn supplements including school-specific essays for each undergraduate school, 'Why Penn?' essay, and additional short answers
essay_requirements.essay_philosophy: Penn wants to see specific knowledge of the university's offerings and genuine enthusiasm. Essays should demonstrate interdisciplinary thinking, practical application mindset, and fit with specific undergraduate school.
what_makes_strong_essays: Specific Penn programs, courses, professors, or opportunities mentioned
Understanding of interdisciplinary resources (dual degrees, minors, coordinated programs)
Clear fit with specific undergraduate school (College, Wharton, Engineering, Nursing)
How you'll connect theory to practice
Genuine passion and clear academic/career interests
Understanding of Penn's urban Ivy character
Specific ways you'll engage with Philadelphia community
Interdisciplinary interests and connections
common_essay_mistakes: Generic 'Why Penn' without specific programs or resources
Not differentiating between undergraduate schools
Missing interdisciplinary opportunities in essays
Weak Wharton essays that don't show business interest foundation
Not connecting classroom learning to real-world application
Ignoring Philadelphia location and community engagement
Listing famous programs without personal connection

extracurriculars.importance: Very high - Penn evaluates both achievement and practical application
extracurriculars.depth_vs_breadth: Depth and sustained leadership strongly preferred
extracurriculars.leadership_expectations: Leadership highly valued, especially showing initiative and impact
extracurriculars.impact_demonstration: Must show tangible outcomes and sustained commitment. Penn values practical application of interests.
extracurriculars.recognition_level: Mix of high-level recognition and deep community impact
extracurriculars.unique_preference: Business/entrepreneurship, community engagement, interdisciplinary projects, activities showing real-world application of knowledge

letters_of_recommendation.requirements: Two teacher recommendations plus counselor recommendation
what_reviewers_look_for: Specific examples of impact and achievement
letters_of_recommendation.importance: Very important - strong recommendations can significantly boost application

demonstrated_interest.importance: Considered - Penn values genuine interest demonstrated through campus visits, essays, and engagement
demonstrated_interest.interviews: Alumni interviews strongly encouraged when available, evaluative

evaluation_rubrics.selection_process: Applications read by regional officers, strong applications get multiple reads and committee discussion
evaluation_rubrics.committee_review: Admissions committee makes final decisions after holistic review
evaluation_rubrics.decision_framework: Evaluation based on academic achievement, school-specific fit, interdisciplinary interests, extracurricular impact, and demonstrated interest
key_evaluation_points: Academic excellence and preparation for rigorous curriculum
Recommendations showing classroom excellence and character

unique_insights: Penn is 'urban Ivy' - engaged with Philadelphia community and city resources
Four undergraduate schools require different preparation: College (liberal arts), Wharton (business), Engineering, Nursing
Interdisciplinary opportunities are exceptional - dual degrees, coordinated programs, minors across schools
Pre-professional culture stronger than other Ivies - practical application valued
Benjamin Franklin's vision of practical education still shapes institutional culture
Strong entrepreneurship ecosystem and business mindset across schools
Demonstrated interest matters more at Penn than some other top schools
Wharton is world's top undergraduate business program - extremely competitive
Penn has highest percentage of international students among Ivies
common_pitfalls: Not understanding differences between Penn's four undergraduate schools
Weak 'Why Penn' essays without specific knowledge
Missing Penn's interdisciplinary strengths in application
Not demonstrating genuine interest through essays and engagement
Wharton applicants without clear business interest or foundation
Ignoring Philadelphia location and community engagement opportunities
Generic essays that could apply to any Ivy
Not showing practical application mindset
Underestimating importance of alumni interview
red_flags: Lack of specific knowledge about Penn's programs and resources
No clear fit with chosen undergraduate school
Wharton applicants with no business/economics background

counselor_perspectives.overall_philosophy: Duke seeks students who are curious, collaborative, and committed to making a positive impact. We look for students who will engage deeply with their education, contribute to our vibrant community, and connect learning with purpose.
counselor_perspectives.mission_alignment: Duke's focus on 'knowledge in service to society' drives admissions. The university values students who combine academic excellence with community engagement and demonstrate how they'll use their Duke education to make a difference.
what_they_seek: Connecting learning with purpose - 'knowledge in service to society'
Students who will engage with DukeEngage and service opportunities
counselor_perspectives.evaluation_philosophy: Duke's holistic review emphasizes both achievement and character. They seek students who show intellectual vitality, commitment to others, and desire to make positive impact.

academic_criteria.gpa_expectations: Most admitted students in top 10% of class, typically 3.9-4.0 unweighted GPA

test_scores.superscoring: Yes, Duke superscores SAT and ACT

academic_criteria.course_rigor: Most demanding curriculum available. Duke expects strong preparation across disciplines.
academic_criteria.academic_interests: Values interdisciplinary interests - students explore across Trinity College of Arts & Sciences and Pratt School of Engineering

essay_requirements.supplemental_essays: Multiple Duke supplements including 'Why Duke?' and prompts about community, learning, and purpose
essay_requirements.essay_philosophy: Duke wants to see genuine connection between your interests and Duke's mission. Essays should demonstrate understanding of 'knowledge in service to society' and how you'll contribute to collaborative community.
what_makes_strong_essays: Specific Duke programs and opportunities (DukeEngage, Bass Connections, etc.)
Understanding of service and impact orientation
How you connect learning with purpose
Genuine enthusiasm for Duke's collaborative culture
Balance between achievement and character
Specific examples of community engagement
Understanding of Trinity vs. Pratt (Engineering)
Authentic voice and reflection
common_essay_mistakes: Generic 'Why Duke' without specific programs
Not mentioning service or community engagement
Missing Duke's 'knowledge in service to society' mission
Weak differentiation between Trinity and Pratt
Focusing only on basketball/campus beauty without academic substance
Not demonstrating collaborative spirit
Listing programs without personal connection

extracurriculars.importance: Very high - Duke evaluates leadership, service, and impact
extracurriculars.depth_vs_breadth: Depth and sustained commitment strongly preferred
extracurriculars.leadership_expectations: Leadership highly valued, especially in service-oriented activities
extracurriculars.impact_demonstration: Must show tangible impact on community. Service and engagement are central to Duke's mission.
extracurriculars.recognition_level: Mix of high-level achievement and deep community service
extracurriculars.unique_preference: Service and community engagement, collaborative projects, activities connecting learning with impact

letters_of_recommendation.requirements: Two teacher recommendations plus counselor recommendation; optional additional recommendation
what_reviewers_look_for: Collaborative spirit and relationship with peers
letters_of_recommendation.importance: Very important - character and community engagement should come through in recommendations

demonstrated_interest.interviews: Alumni interviews offered when available, strongly encouraged

evaluation_rubrics.selection_process: Applications read by regional admissions officers, strong applications discussed in committee
evaluation_rubrics.committee_review: Full committee review for competitive applicants
evaluation_rubrics.decision_framework: Holistic evaluation of academic achievement, character, service, leadership, and fit with Duke's mission

unique_insights: DukeEngage provides funded summer service experiences globally - admissions looks for service-oriented students
Bass Connections links faculty and students across disciplines for research on societal challenges
Trinity College (Arts & Sciences) and Pratt School (Engineering) have different cultures but shared values
Durham location and community engagement are important - Duke partners with local community
Balance between academic excellence and strong athletics/spirit (Cameron Crazies, Duke basketball)
'Knowledge in service to society' is not just motto - it shapes curriculum and student culture
Robertson Scholars Program (Duke-UNC partnership) attracts top students committed to public service
Gothic architecture and campus beauty mentioned by many students, but substance matters more than aesthetics in admissions
common_pitfalls: Not demonstrating service orientation or community engagement
Weak 'Why Duke' without mentioning service mission or specific programs
Focusing on basketball/sports culture without academic substance
Missing connection between learning and purpose
Generic essays that could apply to any top university
Not understanding Trinity vs. Pratt differences
Shallow community service without genuine commitment
Underestimating importance of character and collaboration
red_flags: No evidence of service or community engagement
Lack of specific Duke knowledge in application
Generic application without connection to Duke's mission
Recommendations that don't show character or collaborative spirit
Essays focused only on prestige/rankings without understanding values
